questions.text: A diabetic elderly man presents with dyspnea and pedal edema. A chest X-ray (CXR) shows an enlarged heart with rales. Echo reveals a low ejection fraction (EF). Which of the following treatments will delay the progression of cardiac disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a medication that belongs to the class of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. Although it is primarily used to manage diabetes by promoting glucose excretion through urine, it has been found to have significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Mechanism of Action in Heart Failure: Empagliflozin improves cardiac outcomes through several mechanisms:

 

  • Reduction in preload and afterload: By promoting diuresis and natriuresis, empagliflozin reduces the volume overload, which is beneficial in heart failure.
  • Improvement in myocardial metabolism: It shifts myocardial substrate utilization from glucose to ketone bodies, which is more energy-efficient for the failing heart.
  • Reduction in cardiac fibrosis and inflammation: Empagliflozin has anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects, which help in reducing cardiac remodeling and progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrochlorothiazide: This is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to manage hypertension and mild fluid retention. However, it does not have significant benefits in delaying the progression of heart failure.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not specifically alter the progression of the disease.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin is used in heart failure to improve symptoms and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, but it does not have a mortality benefit or significantly delay the progression of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, although primarily an anti-diabetic medication, has been shown to significantly benefit patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) by delaying the progression of the disease through its effects on diuresis, myocardial metabolism, and cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine Ca ratio > 0.15

 

Nutritional rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization and growth. The incorrect statement in the context of nutritional rickets is:

 

This is typically seen in primary hyperparathyroidism, not in secondary hyperparathyroidism like that seen in vitamin D deficiency or nutritional rickets. In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is usually low because of the body's attempt to conserve calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

The following points summarize the key biochemical features of nutritional rickets:

 

Option A. Normal Calcium: In many cases of nutritional rickets, serum calcium levels are normal or low-normal at the time of presentation due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which compensates for the low calcium by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

Option B. Low Phosphate: Hypophosphatemia is common in rickets due to decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate and increased renal excretion.

 

Option D. High PTH: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs as a response to hypocalcemia, leading to elevated PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

 

Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D and plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. It directly acts on vitamin D receptors (VDRs) present in the parathyroid gland, leading to a decrease in the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Mechanism of Action: Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphate from the intestines. Elevated levels of calcium in the blood provide negative feedback to the parathyroid glands, which reduces the production of PTH. Additionally, calcitriol directly inhibits the synthesis and secretion of PTH by binding to VDRs in the parathyroid gland. This dual action ensures a reduction in PTH levels, making calcitriol an effective treatment for conditions associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Note - Paricalcitol: A synthetic vitamin D receptor (VDR) agonist used to reduce PTH levels in primary hyperparathyroidism. This drug is related to the Cinacalcet, a calcium sensitizer but this act on the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risedronate: Risedronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, which can sometimes lead to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can reflexively increase PTH levels, rather than decrease them.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is known to cause unexplained hyperparathyroidism and consequently increase PTH levels. It is one of the common causes of unexplained hyperparathyroidism, making it an unsuitable option for decreasing PTH levels.

 

Option D. Diuretics: Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can cause hypocalcemia, which in turn can lead to an increase in PTH levels. Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia, which might decrease PTH levels, but in this question, "diuretics" is mentioned generally, and loop diuretics are more commonly associated with increased PTH levels due to hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

 

Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.

 

Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies, which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, having lost her newborn, is producing breast milk, which risks developing into a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which drug can prevent this complication? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the primary goal is to suppress lactation to prevent milk stasis and subsequent breast abscess formation. Lactation is driven by the hormone prolactin, which is released from the anterior pituitary gland. To suppress milk production, prolactin release must be inhibited.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors, which in turn inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland. By reducing prolactin levels, cabergoline effectively suppresses lactation, thereby reducing the risk of milk stasis and breast abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: This drug is a progesterone receptor antagonist primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: This is an antipsychotic medication that blocks dopamine D2 receptors. Blocking dopamine receptors would actually increase prolactin levels and promote milk production, thus potentially worsening the risk of milk stasis and abscess.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: This drug is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is sometimes used as a galactagogue (to promote milk production). Like chlorpromazine, it would increase prolactin levels and thus is not suitable for preventing lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline, a dopamine receptor agonist, is used to suppress lactation by inhibiting prolactin secretion, thereby preventing complications like milk stasis and breast abscess.

questions.text: Glucose load for screening diabetes in pregnancy is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75 gm

 

Explanation:

 

According to the majority of guidelines, including the WHO, IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups), and DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) guidelines, a 75 gm glucose load is used for screening diabetes in pregnancy.

 

Note - The ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists) guidelines follow a two-step process where the first step involves a 50 gm glucose load for screening, and if positive, a 100 gm glucose load for confirmation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25 gm: Not used in any standard screening protocol.

 

Option B. 50 gm: Used in the initial step of the ACOG two-step screening process, but not the most common single-step screening load.

 

Option D. 100 gm: Used in the second step of the ACOG two-step screening process, not for initial screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For screening diabetes in pregnancy, the 75 gm glucose load is widely used according to various international guidelines, including WHO and IADPSG.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dysphagia for solid foods more than liquid for the last 3 months and has severe cachexia. What will be the best investigation to establish the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy with Biopsy

 

The patient's symptoms of dysphagia for solid foods more than liquids, coupled with severe cachexia, are highly suggestive of esophageal cancer.

 

Dysphagia for solids more than liquids typically indicates a structural problem in the esophagus. Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best initial investigation to directly visualize the esophagus and obtain tissue samples for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manometry: This is used to diagnose neuromuscular disorders of the esophagus, such as achalasia, but not typically used as the first-line investigation for suspected structural problems.

 

Option C. Barium swallow: This can provide imaging of the esophagus but is not as definitive as endoscopy with biopsy for diagnosing cancer.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): This is used for staging of cancer once the diagnosis is established but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with dysphagia predominantly for solids, especially with associated severe cachexia, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis, often indicating esophageal cancer.

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDLr

 

Familial hyperlipidemia, particularly familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. The primary cause of this condition is mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene.

 

Mechanism of Action: The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood into the liver. When there are mutations in the LDLr gene, the receptors are either dysfunctional or deficient. As a result, LDL cholesterol cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. This condition significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases.

 

  • Heterozygous FH: This form is more common and results in moderately high LDL cholesterol levels (200-300 mg/dL). It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Homozygous FH: This form is rarer and more severe, with LDL cholesterol levels potentially reaching 600-700 mg/dL. Individuals with homozygous FH have a very high risk of early cardiovascular events and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ApoE:  Mutations in the ApoE gene cause familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification), which leads to elevated levels of intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and is characterized by the presence of remnant particles in the blood.

 

Option B. ApoCII:  Deficiency in ApoCII causes familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification). This condition is associated with extremely high levels of triglycerides due to impaired lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activation, which is necessary for the breakdown of triglycerides.

 

Option D. ApoB48:  ApoB48 is involved in the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. There is no known condition caused by a deficiency of ApoB48 that leads to familial hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following rules out transudative pleural effusion except? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High fibrin

 

Explanation:

 

Transudative pleural effusions are typically characterized by low protein, low specific gravity, and low cellular content. High fibrin content, on the other hand, is suggestive of an exudative effusion rather than a transudative one.

 

Differentiating features:

 

 

 

Additional information

 

Light's criteria: These are used to differentiate exudative pleural effusions from transudative effusions based on the chemical and cellular characteristics of the pleural fluid.

 

  1. Protein Ratio: If the ratio of the protein content in the pleural effusion to the serum protein is more than 0.5 (or 50%), the effusion is likely an exudate.
  2. LDH Ratio: If the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level in the effusion is more than 60% (or 0.6) of the serum LDH, it indicates that the effusion is likely an exudate.
  3. LDH Upper Limit: If the LDH level in the effusion exceeds two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH as defined by the laboratory, the effusion is likely an exudate.

 

If, any one out of three criteria is positive, then its an exudate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low protein: This is a feature of transudative effusions.

 

Option C. Low specific gravity: This is also a characteristic of transudative effusions.

 

Option D. Low cellular content: This is another feature seen in transudative effusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High fibrin content in pleural fluid is indicative of an exudative effusion, which rules out the diagnosis of a transudative pleural effusion.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

 

The presence of amyloid stroma in the context of a thyroid tumor is indicative of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. These cells are responsible for secreting calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The amyloid stroma seen in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin-derived polypeptides.

 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a unique type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C cells. The hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, which results from calcitonin secretion by these cells.

 

Note -

 

  • The tumor marker for Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC) is thyroglobulin.
  • The tumor marker for Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Askanazy cells: These cells, also known as Hurthle cells, are large eosinophilic cells found in the thyroid gland but are typically associated with Hurthle cell carcinoma, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Hurthle cells: These cells are a variant of follicular cells and are characteristic of Hurthle cell carcinoma. They do not produce amyloid stroma.

 

Option D. Follicular cells: These cells give rise to other types of thyroid cancers, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC). These tumors do not typically feature amyloid stroma and are more commonly associated with thyroglobulin as a tumor marker, not calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.

choices.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

 

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus does not have a high association with APS-1. The association is low and not a characteristic feature of APS-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism is common: Hypoparathyroidism is common and is part of the classic triad of APS-1.

 

Option C. Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high: Mucocutaneous candidiasis is highly associated with APS-1. It is typically the first manifestation, appearing in infancy, and is also the most common manifestation due to underlying immunodeficiency.

 

Option D. Early onset in infancy: Early onset in infancy is characteristic of APS-1, with mucocutaneous candidiasis typically being the first manifestation to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic triad of APS-1:

 

  1. Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  2. Hypoparathyroidism
  3. Addison's disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Churg-Strauss Syndrome is not true?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravascular granulomas

 

 

Explanation:

 

Churg-Strauss Syndrome, now known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), is characterized by extravascular granulomas, not intravascular granulomas. EGPA features granulomatous reactions that are present in tissues or even within the walls of vessels, but they are not typically found inside the vessel lumen (intravascular).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma is a characteristic feature of EGPA. Pulmonary findings dominate the clinical picture, with severe asthmatic attacks being a hallmark presentation. Asthma typically occurs early in the disease course and is present in virtually all patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Peripheral eosinophilia:  Peripheral eosinophilia is a hallmark laboratory finding in EGPA. The characteristic finding is striking eosinophilia, which reaches levels >1000 cells/μL in >80% of patients. This is a key diagnostic criterion for the condition.

 

Option C. Vasculitis of multiple organ systems: EGPA involves vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems. The necrotizing vasculitis involves small- and medium-sized muscular arteries, capillaries, veins, and venules. Common sites of involvement include lungs, skin, cardiovascular system, kidneys, peripheral nervous system, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is characterized by the triad of asthma, peripheral eosinophilia, and vasculitis, with extravascular granulomatous inflammation being a key histopathologic finding. These granulomas are present in tissues or vessel walls, not within the vessel lumen.

choices.text: Increased Amino acids
Raised glucose

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus comes with dizziness. Which of the following would be seen in a patient with hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:  

 

Hyperinsulinemia refers to an elevated level of insulin in the blood.

 

Insulin is a lipogenic hormone, meaning it promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and their storage as triglycerides in adipose tissue. This is due to insulin's ability to activate enzymes involved in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper-ketonemia: Incorrect. Insulin suppresses ketone production, so hyperinsulinemia would prevent the formation of ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Increased Amino acids: Incorrect. Insulin promotes protein synthesis and reduces the level of amino acids in the blood by enhancing their uptake into cells and their incorporation into proteins.

 

Option C. Raised glucose: Incorrect. Hyperinsulinemia lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperinsulinemia promotes increased fatty acid synthesis due to insulin's role as a lipogenic hormone, which enhances the storage of energy in the form of fat.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) History of stroke

 

Explanation:

 

The ABCD2 score is used to assess the risk of developing a subsequent stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

 

The components of the ABCD2 score include:

 

  • A (Age): Age 60 years or older scores 1 point.
  • B (Blood Pressure): Systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher, or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher scores 1 point.
  • C (Clinical Features): Unilateral weakness scores 2 points; speech disturbance without weakness scores 1 point.
  • D (Diabetes): Presence of diabetes scores 1 point.
  • D (Duration of Symptoms): Symptoms lasting 60 minutes or longer score 2 points; symptoms lasting 10-59 minutes score 1 point.

 

History of stroke is not included in the ABCD2 scoring system. Instead, it is a component of other scoring systems, such as the CHADS2 or CHA2DS2-VASc scores, which are used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and to guide anticoagulation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age: Age 60 years or older is a factor in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: The presence of diabetes is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ABCD2 score includes age, blood pressure, clinical features, duration of symptoms, and diabetes. History of stroke is not included in this scoring system but is part of other risk assessment tools like CHADS2 and CHA2DS2-VASc

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis. The symptoms started 3 hours ago. On examination, BP is 200/100 mm Hg. CT head is shown below. Which of the following should not be done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate thrombolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis, and the CT scan shows evidence of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), indicating a hemorrhagic stroke. In the case of hemorrhagic stroke, immediate thrombolysis is contraindicated as it can worsen the bleeding. Thrombolytic agents, such as tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), are used to dissolve clots in ischemic strokes but can be harmful in hemorrhagic strokes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood pressure control: Managing high blood pressure is crucial in patients with hemorrhagic stroke to prevent further bleeding.

 

Option C. Clotting factor administration: In cases of hemorrhagic stroke, administering clotting factors or other agents to help control bleeding may be necessary.

 

Option D. Edema management: Managing cerebral edema is essential to reduce intracranial pressure and prevent further complications in hemorrhagic stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate thrombolysis should never be administered in patients with hemorrhagic stroke, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient's condition.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensory aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms suggest that he is experiencing a type of aphasia where comprehension is impaired, but speech remains fluent. This is characteristic of sensory aphasia (also known as receptive aphasia or fluent aphasia).

 

  • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia): Patients with Wernicke's aphasia can speak fluently but their speech often lacks meaning and they have significant difficulty understanding spoken language. They may produce nonsensical and made-up words. This type of aphasia is typically due to a lesion in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area).

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Motor aphasia (Broca's aphasia): This is a non-fluent aphasia where patients have good comprehension but struggle to produce speech. Speech is typically halting and effortful, and patients may be able to produce only short phrases. This is not consistent with the fluent speech described in the case.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Patients with anomic aphasia primarily have difficulty naming objects but otherwise have intact comprehension and fluency. This does not align with the patient’s production of nonsensical words.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This type is characterized by good comprehension and fluent speech, but patients have significant difficulty with repetition. The primary issue in conduction aphasia is the disconnection between comprehension and speech production areas, typically due to damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This does not fully explain the nonsensical speech observed in the patient.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Sensory aphasia, also known as Wernicke's aphasia, is characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension, fitting the described symptoms in this patient.

questions.text: Increased firing of which of the following is responsible for the occurrence of scissoring gait? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Scissoring gait is characterized by the crossing of the legs while walking, which resembles the closing of a pair of scissors. This gait abnormality is primarily due to increased tone and overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs, which are responsible for bringing the legs together.

 

The adductor muscles are innervated by the obturator nerve. Increased firing or hyperactivity of the obturator nerve leads to excessive contraction of the adductor muscles, resulting in the scissoring motion seen in this gait disorder.

 

Treatment options for scissoring gait may include interventions such as obturator nerve cryoneurolysis, where the obturator nerve is intentionally damaged to reduce muscle spasticity and improve gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: This nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the thigh, including the quadriceps muscles, which are involved in knee extension, not adduction.

 

Option B. Superior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, which are involved in hip abduction and stabilization, not adduction.

 

Option C. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle, which is primarily responsible for hip extension and lateral rotation, not adduction.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Scissoring gait is caused by increased firing of the obturator nerve, leading to overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a serious fungal infection that commonly affects immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV. The standard first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis involves an induction therapy phase, typically with a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days. This regimen is effective in reducing the fungal burden and improving outcomes in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin: This antibiotic is used primarily for bacterial infections, particularly those caused by Gram-positive bacteria. It is not effective against fungal infections such as cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. High dose fluconazole: While fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, it is generally used after the initial induction phase with amphotericin B and flucytosine. High dose fluconazole can be part of the consolidation or maintenance therapy.

 

Option C. Voriconazole: This antifungal is primarily used for infections caused by Aspergillus species and is not the preferred treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-positive patients, the first-line induction therapy is a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presented with shortness of breath. On examination, she had bibasal crackles and S3. Echocardiogram revealed poor cardiac contractility with an EF of 33%. Which of the following drugs can reduce mortality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisoprolol

 

This patient has heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF), as indicated by the presence of an S3 heart sound, bibasal crackles, and an ejection fraction (EF) of 33%. The treatment of HF-REF aims to improve symptoms, prevent hospitalization, and reduce mortality. Beta-blockers are a key component of therapy that can significantly reduce mortality in HF-REF patients.

 

Among beta-blockers, only three have been shown to reduce mortality in HF-REF: metoprolol, bisoprolol, and carvedilol. These drugs improve heart function by reducing heart rate, decreasing myocardial oxygen demand, and preventing arrhythmias. Bisoprolol is cardioselective, targeting the heart specifically, which makes it a preferred choice in many cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that is not indicated for heart failure management. It does not reduce mortality in HF-REF and is primarily used for other conditions like migraine prophylaxis and anxiety.

 

Option C. Pindolol: A non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, which is not beneficial in heart failure. Pindolol is not recommended for heart failure and does not reduce mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Labetalol: A combined alpha and beta-blocker primarily used for hypertensive emergencies. It does not have mortality benefits in heart failure patients and is not a recommended drug for HF-REF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key beta-blockers that reduce mortality in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF) are bisoprolol, metoprolol, and carvedilol.

choices.text: Dissecting aneurysm of arch of aorta

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice for the past month. MRI of the patient is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Saccular aneurysm of aortic arch

 

The MRI (or CECT image) of the patient shows a saccular aneurysm originating from the aortic arch. A saccular aneurysm is characterized by an outpouching or sac-like bulge on one side of the blood vessel. The imaging clearly depicts this sac-like protrusion from the aortic arch, which is the hallmark of a saccular aneurysm. Additionally, the 3D reconstruction confirms this finding, showing the aneurysm arising from the aortic arch.

 

This aneurysm's location and size suggest that it may be compressing nearby structures, such as the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which can cause hoarseness of voice, as seen in this patient. Hoarseness is a typical clinical feature when the aneurysm impinges on the nerve, further supporting the diagnosis of a saccular aneurysm of the aortic arch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dissecting aneurysm of arch of aorta: A dissecting aneurysm involves a tear within the wall of the aorta that creates a false lumen. The imaging does not show the classic features of a dissection, such as a flap or double lumen, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Coarctation of aorta: Coarctation refers to a narrowing of the aorta, typically near the ductus arteriosus. It would present differently on imaging, showing a narrowing segment rather than an aneurysmal outpouching. The patient’s symptoms do not align with coarctation, which often presents with hypertension and diminished pulses rather than hoarseness.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: This condition would present with a characteristic tear and separation of the layers of the aortic wall. Imaging would typically show a double lumen appearance, which is absent here. The patient's symptoms and the MRI findings do not match this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A saccular aneurysm of the aortic arch can present with chest pain and hoarseness due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Recognition of the aneurysmal sac on imaging is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient presented with chest pain, shortness of breath, and edema. On examination, his pulse was irregularly irregular, his JVP was elevated and showed a prominent ‘Y’ descent. On auscultation, he had a high-pitched diastolic sound. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Constrictive Pericarditis

 

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by the thickening and calcification of the pericardium, which restricts diastolic filling of the heart. Key findings in this condition include elevated JVP with a prominent ‘Y’ descent, irregularly irregular pulse, and signs of systemic congestion like edema. The high-pitched diastolic sound referred to as a pericardial knock is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis and reflects the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling.

 

The prominent ‘Y’ descent in JVP is particularly significant in constrictive pericarditis and is also known as Friderich’s sign. This sign, along with the clinical presentation of chest pain, shortness of breath, and irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation, strongly supports the diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bicuspid Aortic Valve with AR: This condition typically presents with a diastolic murmur and symptoms of heart failure but does not produce a prominent ‘Y’ descent in JVP. The absence of pericardial knock and the presentation with irregularly irregular pulse make this option unlikely.

 

Option B. RHD with MS: Rheumatic heart disease with mitral stenosis typically shows an elevated JVP with prominent ‘a’ waves rather than a ‘Y’ descent. Also, it is associated with a low-pitched diastolic rumble, not a high-pitched sound or pericardial knock.

 

Option D. Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade presents with elevated JVP, but it shows a blunted or absent ‘Y’ descent due to the restricted filling of the heart chambers. The clinical presentation does not align with the typical features of tamponade, such as pulsus paradoxus or muffled heart sounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent ‘Y’ descent in JVP along with a high-pitched diastolic sound (pericardial knock) and symptoms of systemic congestion are hallmark features of constrictive pericarditis.

choices.text: Pressure overload increases myocardial demand more than volume overload
Volume overload increases myocardial demand more than pressure overload
AS does not cause pressure overload
Preload increases myocardial oxygen demand more than afterload

questions.text: What is the reason for a patient who has aortic stenosis experience easy fatigue as compared to a patient with aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure overload increases myocardial demand more than volume overload

 

In aortic stenosis, there is a fixed obstruction in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT), leading to increased pressure within the left ventricle. This condition is known as pressure overload.

 

The left ventricle undergoes hypertrophy to compensate for the increased pressure, which significantly increases myocardial oxygen consumption.

 

This heightened demand for oxygen and energy is the primary reason patients with aortic stenosis experience easy fatigue, angina, and potential heart failure over time.

 

The increased myocardial demand due to pressure overload is significantly higher than that seen in volume overload, which is typical in aortic regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volume overload increases myocardial demand more than pressure overload: This option is incorrect because, in aortic regurgitation, the left ventricle faces volume overload rather than pressure overload. While volume overload does increase myocardial demand, it is less severe compared to the pressure overload seen in aortic stenosis, which leads to a greater increase in oxygen consumption and energy demand.

 

Option C. AS does not cause pressure overload: This statement is incorrect because aortic stenosis (AS) is characterized by pressure overload due to the obstruction of blood flow through the aortic valve, which significantly raises left ventricular pressure.

 

Option D. Preload increases myocardial oxygen demand more than afterload: Preload refers to the volume of blood in the ventricles at the end of diastole, while afterload refers to the resistance the heart must overcome to eject blood. In aortic stenosis, it is the pressure overload (similar to afterload) that increases myocardial oxygen demand more than preload, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic stenosis causes pressure overload, which increases myocardial oxygen demand significantly, leading to symptoms like fatigue, angina, and heart failure.

questions.text: A patient with hypertension and CKD presented with generalized tiredness. ECG is taken and shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperkalemia

 

The ECG shown in the question exhibits classic features of hyperkalemia. Key findings include:

 

  1. Tall T Waves: This is a hallmark sign of hyperkalemia, often appearing as sharply peaked T waves on the ECG.
  2. Wide QRS Complexes: The widening of the QRS complex suggests conduction blocks, which are a frequent occurrence in severe hyperkalemia.
  3. Absence of P Waves: In the rhythm strip, especially in lead II, the absence of P waves suggests atrial paralysis, which indicates severe impairment of atrial conduction often due to hyperkalemia.
  4. Combination of Conduction Blocks and Overexcitation: Hyperkalemia is unique in that it can cause both conduction blocks and arrhythmias due to the overexcitation of the myocardium.

 

These findings collectively confirm the diagnosis of hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia typically presents with flattened T waves, U waves, and prolonged QT intervals, none of which are observed in the provided ECG.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: Hyponatremia does not have specific ECG findings that match the abnormalities described in this case. It generally presents with non-specific ECG changes.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia usually shows a prolonged QT interval and occasionally T wave changes but does not cause the absence of P waves, tall T waves, or wide QRS complexes seen in this ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is characterized by tall T waves, wide QRS complexes, and absence of P waves on an ECG, indicative of conduction blocks and atrial paralysis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD developed breathlessness and is on mechanical ventilation. He suddenly developed hypoxia, and on examination, he has reduced/absent breath sounds on the left hemithorax with increased peak inspiratory pressure. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumothorax

 

Pneumothorax is a common complication in ICU patients, particularly those on mechanical ventilation. It is often caused by barotrauma, which can lead to an acute deterioration in ventilated patients, presenting with sudden hypoxemia and increased peak inspiratory pressure (PIP). The clinical signs of absent or reduced breath sounds on one side strongly indicate pneumothorax. In such cases, increased PIP is due to the poor lung compliance caused by air in the pleural space, compromising the lung's ability to expand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Exacerbation: Acute exacerbation of COPD usually presents with worsening dyspnea, increased sputum production, or change in sputum color, not sudden absence of breath sounds on one side. There is no specific mention of plateau pressure changes that would suggest this diagnosis, making it unlikely in this context.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism generally causes hypoxia and sudden respiratory distress but does not specifically lead to absent breath sounds on one side or increased PIP. Instead, PIP would typically remain normal, as it is an extrapulmonary cause of respiratory deterioration.

 

Option D. Pneumonia: Pneumonia could present with hypoxia but is usually associated with bronchial breath sounds or signs of consolidation rather than absent breath sounds on one side. The examination findings and increased PIP make pneumonia an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumothorax should be considered in ventilated patients with sudden respiratory deterioration, absent breath sounds on one side, and increased peak inspiratory pressure.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the Chest X Ray?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The chest X-ray shows a clear sign of air under the diaphragm, which is a classic radiographic finding indicating a hollow viscus perforation. This condition typically results from the perforation of any part of the gastrointestinal tract, such as the stomach, intestines, or colon, leading to the escape of air into the peritoneal cavity.

 

The key diagnostic clue in the X-ray is the presence of free air under the diaphragm, which appears as a crescent of radiolucency (dark area) beneath the dome of the diaphragm. This finding is an emergency and requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Everted hemidiaphragm: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it involves the abnormal elevation of one side of the diaphragm due to various causes such as phrenic nerve paralysis, but does not produce the characteristic air under the diaphragm seen in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Intestinal obstruction: While this condition can cause significant abdominal pain and distension, it does not typically result in the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray. Instead, intestinal obstruction is diagnosed via abdominal X-rays or CT scans showing dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels.

 

Option D. Hyperinflated lungs: This is usually seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and would show an increased lung volume and flattened diaphragms on the X-ray, but not free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray is a hallmark sign of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with sudden breathlessness. X-ray of the patient is shown. What is likely to be heard on auscultation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent sounds

 

The patient presents with sudden breathlessness, and the X-ray reveals signs consistent with pneumothorax, including a collapsed lung with hyperlucent areas in the pleural space. Pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse and preventing normal lung expansion. In tension pneumothorax, there may also be a shift of the trachea and mediastinum due to increased pressure.

 

On auscultation, absent or significantly reduced breath sounds are typically heard on the affected side due to the collapse of the lung and the presence of air in the pleural space preventing sound transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicular: Vesicular breath sounds are normal sounds heard over healthy lung tissue. They are soft and low-pitched. In the case of pneumothorax, these sounds would not be heard over the affected area because the lung is collapsed.

 

Option B. Bronchial: Bronchial breath sounds are usually heard over the trachea and are high-pitched with a distinct pause between inspiration and expiration. These sounds are not typically heard in pneumothorax; instead, there would be absent or reduced breath sounds due to the collapse of the lung.

 

Option D. Bronchovesicular: These sounds are intermediate between bronchial and vesicular and are typically heard over the main bronchi. In pneumothorax, however, breath sounds would be absent or reduced on the affected side, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumothorax is characterized by absent or reduced breath sounds on the affected side during auscultation due to the collapse of the lung.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used for the treatment of constipation-predominant Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS-C)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lubiprostone

 

Lubiprostone is specifically indicated for the treatment of IBS-C (IBS with constipation). It functions as a prosecretory agent that activates intestinal chloride channels, increasing intestinal fluid secretion and promoting bowel movements. This mechanism makes it particularly effective for constipation-predominant IBS, helping to alleviate both the constipation and associated discomfort in affected patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant primarily used to treat bile acid malabsorption (BAM). While it can affect bowel function, it is not indicated for IBS-C treatment and may actually worsen constipation in some patients. It's mainly used when excess bile acids are contributing to diarrhea.

 

Option C. Alosetron: Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that has a constipating effect and is used in specific cases of severe diarrhea-predominant IBS (IBS-D) in women who have failed conventional therapy. It would be contraindicated in IBS-C as it would worsen constipation.

 

Option D. Rifaximin: Rifaximin is a non-absorbable antibiotic used in IBS-D (diarrhea-predominant IBS), not IBS-C. It targets bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine which may contribute to IBS-D symptoms. It has no established therapeutic role in treating constipation-predominant IBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of IBS should be targeted to the predominant symptom pattern. Lubiprostone specifically addresses constipation in IBS-C by increasing intestinal fluid secretion, whereas other agents like rifaximin are indicated for diarrhea-predominant IBS (IBS-D).

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Palpitations
  2. Elevated BNP Troponins
  3. Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo
  4. ECG suggestive of myocarditis
  5. Low LVEF in echo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5


Subclinical myocarditis may not present with symptoms like palpitations, but can show:

 

2. Elevated BNP/Troponins: Indicating myocardial injury.

3. Regional wall motion abnormalities: Seen on echocardiography.

4. ECG changes: Suggestive of myocarditis, such as non-specific ST-T changes.

5. Low LVEF: Indicative of impaired left ventricular function.

 

Other Option:
 

1. Palpitations are not a feature of subclinical myocarditis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.

 

Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.

 

 

Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisoning? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocarbon

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in two types of poisoning: Hydrocarbon and corrosive poisoning. 

 

Hydrocarbons are substances such as gasoline, kerosene, or certain cleaning agents, which are highly volatile and can easily be aspirated into the lungs during the procedure. This can lead to severe chemical pneumonitis and other respiratory complications, making the risks of gastric lavage significantly higher than any potential benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Gastric lavage is not typically contraindicated in phenytoin poisoning. While it is not the first line of treatment, it can be considered if the patient presents soon after ingestion.

 

Option C. Unknown poisoning within 1 hour: For unknown poisoning, especially if within 1 hour of ingestion, gastric lavage might still be considered, although it is generally falling out of favor due to risks and effectiveness. However, it is not specifically contraindicated.

 

Option D. Paracetamol: Gastric lavage is not contraindicated in paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning. The mainstay of treatment for paracetamol poisoning is N-acetylcysteine (NAC) administration, but if the patient presents early, gastric lavage can be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning due to the high risk of aspiration and subsequent chemical pneumonitis. In any case of poisoning, the potential risks and benefits of gastric lavage must be carefully considered.

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is unique in that it increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. GH plays a crucial role in growth, metabolism, and overall bodily repair and regeneration. During deep sleep, especially during slow-wave sleep, GH secretion peaks. This is vital for tissue growth and repair.

 

Stress and starvation also trigger the release of GH, which helps in mobilizing fat stores for energy and preserving muscle mass, among other functions. These adaptive responses are crucial for survival during periods of physical or emotional stress and food scarcity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids:  These hormones, which include cortisol, increase in response to stress and starvation. However, their levels typically decrease during deep sleep and peak in the early morning hours.

 

Option C. Cortisol:  A specific glucocorticoid that increases in response to stress and starvation, but like other glucocorticoids, its levels decrease during deep sleep and peak early in the morning.

 

Option D. Prolactin:  This hormone can increase in response to stress and has a role in metabolism and immune regulation, but it does not have the same peak during deep sleep as GH does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is the hormone that increases during periods of stress, starvation, and especially deep sleep, distinguishing it from other hormones that typically decrease during deep sleep.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache and neck stiffness. CT scan of the head and angiogram is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subarachnoid hemorrhage


The CT scan shows a characteristic pattern known as the "star of death," which is highly indicative of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). This pattern occurs due to the accumulation of blood in the subarachnoid space, often visible on CT as a star-shaped density in the basal cisterns. This appearance is typical of subarachnoid hemorrhage, especially in cases involving a ruptured cerebral aneurysm, which is a common cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meningitis: This condition can also present with headache and neck stiffness, but it does not cause the specific imaging pattern seen here. Meningitis would typically show signs of inflammation in the meninges, such as enhancement or thickening on imaging, rather than acute hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Ischemic stroke: Ischemic stroke usually presents as areas of hypodensity due to loss of blood supply and is not associated with acute bleeding. The CT appearance here does not match the typical signs of ischemic stroke.

 

Option D. Migraine: Migraines can cause severe headaches but do not cause changes on CT scans. There are no structural changes such as hemorrhage or other abnormalities that are diagnostic of migraines on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:


The "star of death" pattern on a CT scan is a hallmark of subarachnoid hemorrhage, usually due to a ruptured aneurysm. Recognizing this pattern is crucial in diagnosing SAH.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoid

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for producing different types of hormones. The mnemonic "GFR" can help remember the order and function of these zones:

 

  • Zona glomerulosa: Produces mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone), which are involved in regulating salt and water balance.
  • Zona fasciculata: Produces glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol), which play a key role in glucose metabolism, stress response, and immune function.
  • Zona reticularis: Produces androgens (e.g., dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione), which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

The zona fasciculata specifically secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which is involved in various physiological processes including metabolism, immune response, and stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mineralocorticoid: This hormone is produced by the zona glomerulosa, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option C. Androgen: These hormones are produced by the zona reticularis, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is produced by the adrenal medulla, not the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex is responsible for producing glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who presents with ptosis and muscle weakness was found to improve on rest. She was later diagnosed to have myasthenia gravis. Now she complains of dysphagia and has engorged veins on the thorax. CT scan is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The patient's symptoms, including ptosis and muscle weakness that improve on rest, are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, an autoimmune disorder affecting neuromuscular transmission. Thymoma is a common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with myasthenia gravis, occurring in approximately 15% of cases. The presence of an anterior mediastinal mass on the CT scan strongly suggests thymoma. In myasthenia gravis, thymoma is a notable associated tumor, making it the most likely diagnosis when an anterior mediastinal mass is observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pancoast tumor: Pancoast tumors are located at the apex of the lung and are typically associated with symptoms like shoulder pain, Horner’s syndrome, and arm weakness due to involvement of the brachial plexus. They do not commonly present with anterior mediastinal masses or myasthenia gravis.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a type of lung cancer that usually presents with pulmonary symptoms and not typically as an anterior mediastinal mass. It is not commonly linked with myasthenia gravis.

 

Option D. Ectopic thyroid gland: Ectopic thyroid tissue can appear in the mediastinum but does not typically present with symptoms like dysphagia and engorged thoracic veins, nor is it associated with myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When myasthenia gravis is present with an anterior mediastinal mass, the diagnosis is most likely thymoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for 4 months. Her ALP levels are elevated, but serum calcium and phosphorus levels are normal, and X-ray of the patient is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's Disease

 

Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and weakening of bones. The most commonly affected areas include the pelvis, skull, spine, and legs. In Paget's disease, the process of bone remodeling is disrupted, leading to an imbalance between the breakdown and formation of bone tissue. This results in the formation of structurally abnormal bone, which can cause pain, deformities, and an increased risk of fractures.

 

In this case, the patient presents with bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, which are characteristic findings of Paget's disease. The X-ray showing multiple small spots and thickening of the calvarium is also typical of Paget's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects younger individuals and presents with localized bone pain and swelling. It is associated with elevated ALP but usually involves more aggressive bone destruction and periosteal reaction on imaging.

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It presents with pain and swelling and is associated with a characteristic "onion skin" appearance on X-ray. The patient's age and the X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that usually presents as a painless, palpable mass near the ends of long bones in adolescents and young adults. It does not typically present with elevated ALP or the described X-ray findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of bone is characterized by bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, with characteristic X-ray findings such as thickening of the calvarium

questions.text: Which of the following set of values suggest primary hypothyroidism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low T4; High TSH

 

Primary hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland itself is not producing enough thyroid hormones (T4 and T3). This deficiency in thyroid hormone production leads to a decrease in circulating T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds to low T4 levels by increasing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormones.

 

Thus, in primary hypothyroidism, the typical laboratory findings are:

 

  • Low T4: Indicates underproduction of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.
  • High TSH: Indicates the pituitary gland's response to low thyroid hormone levels by secreting more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests secondary (or central) hypothyroidism, where the problem lies either in the pituitary gland (which produces TSH) or the hypothalamus (which produces TRH that stimulates TSH production). Both T4 and TSH are low because the pituitary gland is not secreting enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. High T4; High TSH: This pattern is indicative of central hyperthyroidism, where there is excessive production of TSH from the pituitary gland, leading to an overactive thyroid and high levels of T4.

 

Option D. High T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests primary hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroid hormone, leading to high T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds by reducing TSH production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by low T4 levels and high TSH levels due to the thyroid gland's failure to produce sufficient thyroid hormones and the pituitary gland's compensatory increase in TSH secretion.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cretinism

 

The child presents with symptoms that are highly characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, also known as cretinism. These symptoms include dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), and umbilical hernia. Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that arises from insufficient thyroid hormone production at birth. If untreated, it can lead to mental retardation and developmental delays. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. It does not typically present with macroglossia or umbilical hernia.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, Edward syndrome presents with severe intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and distinct facial features. While it can present with a range of symptoms, dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia are not typical features.

 

Option D. Galactosemia: This metabolic disorder is due to an inability to metabolize galactose properly. Symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, poor weight gain, and lethargy. It does not typically present with macroglossia, dry skin, or rough hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs that stimulate the pancreas to release more insulin. This increased insulin release can lower blood glucose levels significantly, leading to hypoglycemia, especially if meals are skipped or physical activity is increased. Sulfonylureas are well known for their potential to cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: This drug primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It rarely causes hypoglycemia when used alone because it does not directly stimulate insulin release.

 

Option C. Acarbose:  An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that slows carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It does not cause hypoglycemia when used alone, as it does not affect insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Dapagliflozin:  A sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that promotes glucose excretion in the urine. It has a low risk of causing hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not increase insulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group of drugs that tend to produce hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy:

 

  • Insulin
  • Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. One of the well-known side effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increased risk of fungal infections, particularly candidal infections of the genital tract. This is because SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, creating an environment conducive to fungal growth. Therefore, in patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, such as the 60-year-old female in this case, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: The most common side effect of metformin is gastrointestinal upset, particularly diarrhea. It does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: This sulfonylurea drug primarily causes hypoglycemia as a side effect. It does not have a significant association with increased risk of fungal infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: This drug can cause weight gain due to fluid retention but does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: A patient presented with Horner’s syndrome. It is due to involvement of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Muller’s muscle

 

Horner's syndrome is characterized by a triad of symptoms: ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face. These symptoms result from disruption of the sympathetic nerves supplying the eye and surrounding structures.

 

Ptosis in Horner’s syndrome specifically occurs due to the involvement of Muller’s muscle (superior tarsal muscle), which is a smooth muscle that receives sympathetic innervation. The loss of sympathetic input causes the muscle to relax, leading to a slight drooping of the eyelid, which is less pronounced compared to ptosis caused by other conditions like third nerve palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levator palpebrae superioris: This muscle is responsible for lifting the eyelid and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). Its dysfunction leads to significant ptosis, as seen in third nerve palsy, not Horner's syndrome. In Horner’s syndrome, this muscle is not affected.

 

Option C. Superior rectus: This extraocular muscle is involved in elevating the eye and is not responsible for eyelid movement. It is not involved in Horner’s syndrome.

 

Option D. External Oblique: This is an abdominal muscle and has no role in eye movements or eyelid function. It is unrelated to Horner’s syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis in Horner’s syndrome is due to the involvement of Muller’s muscle, which loses its sympathetic innervation, causing a mild drooping of the upper eyelid.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presented with weakness and fatigue. His BP was 80/60 mm Hg and his reports showed a serum Na+ of 127 mEq/L and serum K+ of 5.2 mEq/L. On examination, the patient had hyperpigmentation in the knuckles, arms, and legs. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary adrenal insufficiency

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison's disease, is characterized by inadequate production of adrenal hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone. The clinical presentation typically includes fatigue, weakness, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances such as hyponatremia (low sodium) and hyperkalemia (high potassium). The physical finding of hyperpigmentation, especially in areas like the knuckles, arms, and legs, is a classic feature due to increased production of ACTH, which has melanocyte-stimulating activity.

 

In this case, the combination of fatigue, hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation strongly supports the diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency. The presence of these symptoms is almost pathognomonic for Addison's disease, especially when associated with a history of chronic fatigue and weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conns syndrome: Conn's syndrome, or primary hyperaldosteronism, typically presents with hypertension (high blood pressure) and hypokalemia (low potassium), not hypotension and hyperkalemia. Thus, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency can cause hyperpigmentation, it does not present with the electrolyte abnormalities seen here (hyponatremia and hyperkalemia) or the profound hypotension. The presentation in this case does not align with B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion): SIADH can cause hyponatremia, but it is associated with euvolemia or hypervolemia, not the hypotension, hypovolemia, and hyperkalemia seen in this patient. The presence of hyperkalemia is not typical of SIADH, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) presents with hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation due to low cortisol and aldosterone levels.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis with high anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis with low anion gap

questions.text: Evaluate the arterial blood gas with the following findings: pH 7.26, PaCO₂ - 16 mm Hg, HCO₃ - 8, Na⁺ 135, Cl⁻ - 108, K⁺ - 4.2. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis with high anion gap

 

The patient's ABG shows a pH of 7.26, indicating acidosis. Both the PaCO₂ and bicarbonate (HCO₃) levels are decreased, aligning with the pattern seen in metabolic acidosis. According to the Rome rule, when the pH, PaCO₂, and HCO₃ all move in the same direction, it points toward a metabolic process—in this case, metabolic acidosis.

 

To confirm the presence of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), the anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

 

Since the anion gap is 19 (normal is usually 8-12), this confirms a high anion gap, indicating that the acidosis is due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions. The low PaCO₂ (16 mm Hg) suggests that the body is compensating for the metabolic acidosis through respiratory alkalosis by blowing off CO₂.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis with low anion gap: Respiratory acidosis would present with elevated PaCO₂, not decreased, and compensation would involve increased bicarbonate, not decreased. The scenario presented does not fit this pattern.

 

Option C. Metabolic alkalosis: This would present with an elevated pH, elevated bicarbonate, and often an elevated PaCO₂ due to compensatory hypoventilation. None of these findings align with the presented ABG values.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis would show a high pH with a low PaCO₂, and compensation would involve a drop in bicarbonate. While the PaCO₂ is low, the overall pH is acidic, indicating the primary disturbance is not respiratory alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a low pH, decreased bicarbonate, and decreased PaCO₂ with a calculated high anion gap strongly indicates high anion gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, what is the feature of stage 3 beta cell destruction? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autoimmune +ve dysglycemic symptomatic

 

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus progresses through different stages of beta cell destruction:

 

  • Stage 1: This stage is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies in the circulation, indicating an autoimmune process against pancreatic beta cells. However, the patient maintains normoglycemia (normal blood sugar levels) and remains asymptomatic.
  • Stage 2: In this stage, autoantibodies are still present, but the patient begins to develop dysglycemia, indicating abnormal blood sugar levels that do not yet meet the criteria for diabetes (often in the range of glucose intolerance).
