Despite dysglycemia, patients remain asymptomatic during this stage.
  • Stage 3: This stage is marked by the presence of autoantibodies, dysglycemia, and the onset of clinical symptoms. At this point, most patients meet the criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus as defined by the WHO. Symptoms such as polyuria (frequent urination), polydipsia (excessive thirst), polyphagia (increased hunger), weight loss, and other metabolic and osmotic symptoms associated with high glucose levels become apparent.

 

Therefore, Stage 3 is characterized by positive autoimmunity, dysglycemia, and the presence of symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 3 of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus is characterized by autoimmunity, dysglycemia, and the presence of clinical symptoms, meeting the criteria for diabetes diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Co-trimoxazole only

 

In a patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm presenting with symptoms such as cough and fever, but with a normal chest x-ray, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a likely diagnosis. PCP is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, especially when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/cu.mm.

 

The treatment of choice for PCP is co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). It is essential to start treatment empirically in suspected cases of PCP because delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The dose of co-trimoxazole is typically higher for treating PCP than for prophylaxis.

 

Steroids are indicated in severe cases of PCP to reduce inflammation, specifically if the patient has hypoxemia (PaO2 < 70 mmHg) or an alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient > 35 mmHg. In this scenario, there is no data indicating severe disease, so co-trimoxazole alone is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin: This combination is used for bacterial pneumonia, not PCP. Given the normal chest x-ray and the patient's clinical presentation, bacterial pneumonia is less likely.

 

Option B. Co-trimoxazole + steroids: Steroids are added in severe cases of PCP. However, there is no evidence in this case of severe hypoxemia or an increased A-a gradient to justify the use of steroids along with co-trimoxazole.

 

Option D. Antitubercular treatment: There is no indication from the clinical presentation or the normal chest x-ray that the patient has tuberculosis. Antitubercular treatment is therefore not appropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/cu.mm and presenting with cough and fever but a normal chest x-ray, co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for suspected PCP

 

Note - For a patient with a CD4 count of 200 and lower respiratory tract symptoms:

 

  • PCP Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray is normal or negative.
  • Bacterial Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray shows consolidation or examination reveals bronchial breath sounds.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

 

The ECG presented shows tall P waves in lead II, which are characteristic of P pulmonale. P pulmonale refers to the presence of abnormally tall P waves in the ECG, usually greater than 2.5 mm in height in lead II. This finding indicates right atrial enlargement, which is commonly associated with pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary hypertension. Right atrial enlargement occurs due to increased pressure or volume overload in the right atrium, often secondary to lung diseases that lead to increased pulmonary artery pressures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans is characterized by alternating amplitude or direction of the QRS complexes in the ECG. It is often associated with large pericardial effusions and is not indicated by the tall P waves seen in this ECG.

 

Option C. Ventricular bigeminy: Ventricular bigeminy refers to a rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC). The ECG would show alternating normal QRS complexes with PVCs, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: Improper calibration of an ECG machine would result in uniformly abnormal waves across all leads, which does not match the specific tall P waves observed in lead II in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text: Patient develops severe migratory joint pain after an attack of acute rheumatic fever. How will you manage this patient? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Aspirin. Acute rheumatic fever commonly presents with migratory polyarthritis, which is characterized by severe joint pain that moves from one joint to another.

 

The treatment of choice for this arthritis is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the most effective and commonly used. Aspirin helps to reduce inflammation and pain associated with the arthritis of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a diuretic and is not used for the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever. It may be used in cases of heart failure associated with rheumatic carditis.

 

Option B. Digoxin: This is a cardiac glycoside used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used for managing arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication and has no role in the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for severe migratory joint pain (arthritis) in acute rheumatic fever is the use of NSAIDs, with aspirin being the drug of choice due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and pain.

questions.text: A 65-year-old known case of Parkinson's disease presents with severe oropharyngeal dysphagia and recurrent episodes of aspiration pneumonitis. CXR reveals bilateral bronchiectasis. What is the most appropriate long-term management plan for this patient? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PEG tube

 

The most appropriate long-term management for this patient with end-stage Parkinson's disease, severe oropharyngeal dysphagia, and recurrent aspiration is a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube. 

 

The patient has developed bilateral bronchiectasis as a consequence of recurrent aspiration pneumonitis due to severe dysphagia. 

 

While the other options address bronchiectasis management, they do not address the primary underlying problem - the aspiration due to severe dysphagia. In end-stage neurodegenerative disorders with severe dysphagia and recurrent aspiration, PEG tube placement provides safe nutritional support while preventing further aspiration episodes. This addresses the root cause of the problem and prevents further lung damage from aspiration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-frequency chest wall oscillation therapy: This is a treatment for bronchiectasis to help with airway clearance, but it doesn't address the underlying cause of aspiration that led to bronchiectasis.

 

Option B. Nebulized N-acetylcysteine to reduce secretions: This may help with secretion management in bronchiectasis but doesn't prevent the ongoing aspiration that is causing the problem.

 

Option D. Macrolide therapy: Long-term azithromycin can reduce exacerbations in bronchiectasis and COPD, but it doesn't address the primary aspiration problem and is not curative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In end-stage neurodegenerative disorders with severe dysphagia and recurrent aspiration, PEG tube placement is the most appropriate long-term management to prevent further aspiration and provide safe nutrition.

choices.text: Add a second oral hypoglycemic agent

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is on metformin therapy (500 mg BD). Their recent HbA1c is 7.6%, and their last blood glucose reading was 169 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase the dose of metformin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s HbA1c of 7.6% is above the target of <7%, indicating suboptimal glycemic control.

 

  • Metformin is the first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes
  • The current dose (500 mg BD) is below the maximum effective dose
  • Metformin can be increased up to 2000 mg/day (1000 mg BD) before adding another agent

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue metformin: Incorrect, as it is the first-line treatment for diabetes

 

Option C. Add a second agent: Not necessary until maximizing metformin dose

 

Option D. Initiate insulin therapy: Reserved for severely uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c >9% or symptomatic hyperglycemia)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optimization of metformin dosage (up to 2000 mg/day) should be attempted before adding additional diabetes medications when glycemic control is suboptimal.
